RESEARCH

Bridging Theory and Practice

Exploring the intersection of security, privacy, and distributed machine learning

Research Philosophy

My research operates at the intersection of cryptographic security and distributed machine learning. I believe that robust AI systems require both theoretical foundations and practical implementation‚Äîsecurity mechanisms must work not just in papers, but in real-world deployments with resource constraints and honest-but-curious participants.

I focus on federated learning security because it represents one of the most challenging practical scenarios: distributed training across untrusted devices with strict privacy requirements. My work aims to make these systems resilient to adversarial attacks while maintaining the privacy guarantees that make federated learning valuable in the first place.

EXPLORATION

Active Research Directions

Core questions driving my current research agenda

Q1

Can we build verifiable trust between financial institutions in federated learning without revealing private data?

Exploring zero-knowledge proofs for provable model integrity in cross-institution FL. Traditional approaches require data sharing or trusted third parties‚ÄîI investigate cryptographic methods that allow banks to collaborate on fraud detection while proving they followed the protocol without revealing their training data. Key techniques include ZK-SNARKs for gradient verification and commitment schemes for model update integrity.

Related Literature

  • ‚Ä¢ Bonawitz et al. "Practical Secure Aggregation for FL" (2017) - foundational secure aggregation
  • ‚Ä¢ Weng et al. "AuditFL: Accountable FL via Verifiable Gradients" (2023) - gradient verification
  • ‚Ä¢ Zhang et al. "EZFL: Efficient Zero-Knowledge Proofs for FL" (2024) - ZK-FL integration

Open Questions

  • ? How do ZK-proof sizes scale with model dimension in production settings?
  • ? Can we achieve sub-second verification for real-time fraud detection pipelines?
  • ? What are the minimum cryptographic assumptions for cross-institution trust?
Zero-Knowledge Proofs Federated Learning Financial Systems Trust Verification
Q2

How do we make phishing detection explainable when the model is distributed across institutions?

Investigating local LLMs to generate human-understandable explanations for federated phishing classifiers. The challenge is providing actionable insights to security analysts without centralizing model knowledge or exposing which features each institution contributed. I explore techniques like counterfactual explanations and attention-based interpretability that work in distributed settings.

Related Literature

  • ‚Ä¢ Gramegna & Giudici "Explainable FL for Credit Scoring" (2021) - XAI in distributed finance
  • ‚Ä¢ Singh et al. "FedXAI: Explainable AI for FL" (2023) - federated interpretability framework
  • ‚Ä¢ Liu et al. "Privacy-Preserving Explanations via SHAP" (2022) - private feature attribution

Open Questions

  • ? Can LLM-generated explanations remain faithful without accessing raw feature distributions?
  • ? How do we ensure explanations do not leak private information across institutional boundaries?
  • ? What explanation formats do security analysts actually find actionable?
Explainable AI LLMs Phishing Detection Privacy-Preserving XAI
Q3

What's the real-world cost of Byzantine resilience in production federated systems?

Most FL defense papers benchmark on MNIST/CIFAR with idealized adversary models. I study how defenses like SignGuard perform under realistic banking data distributions‚Äîskewed, imbalanced, and with concept drift. Key metrics include: detection latency impact on real-time scoring, computational overhead on edge devices, and accuracy trade-offs under adaptive attacks targeting specific defense mechanisms.

Related Literature

  • ‚Ä¢ Blanchard et al. "Machine Learning with Adversaries: Byzantine Tolerant Gradient Descent" (2017)
  • ‚Ä¢ Yin et al. "Byzantine-Robust Distributed Learning" (2018) - defense benchmarks
  • ‚Ä¢ Shejwalkar & Houmansadr "Manipulating the Byzantine" (2021) - adaptive attack strategies

Open Questions

  • ? How does defense overhead scale with the fraction of malicious clients?
  • ? What detection latency is acceptable for real-time fraud scoring?
  • ? Do current benchmarks reflect realistic adversary capabilities and incentives?
Byzantine Resilience Production FL Empirical Security Performance Analysis

Federated Learning Security

Byzantine-resilient federated learning for secure cross-institution collaboration

Key Areas

  • ‚Ä¢ SignGuard: 94.5% attack detection with ECDSA + Anomaly Detection + Reputation
  • ‚Ä¢ Secure aggregation with Shamir's Secret Sharing
  • ‚Ä¢ Privacy attacks: membership inference, gradient leakage, property inference
  • ‚Ä¢ Byzantine-robust aggregation: Krum, Multi-Krum, FoolsGold

Steganography & Information Hiding

Published research in steganographic methods using PVD, LSB, and modulo encoding

Key Areas

  • ‚Ä¢ PVD + LSB + Modulo Encoding implementation
  • ‚Ä¢ NIST SP 800-90A CTR_DRBG with AES-128
  • ‚Ä¢ Channel optimization for reduced distortion
  • ‚Ä¢ Testing across 131 images with 10 message sizes each

Malware Analysis & Detection

Static analysis framework for banking trojan detection

Key Areas

  • ‚Ä¢ API call sequence extraction
  • ‚Ä¢ YARA rule development and matching
  • ‚Ä¢ ML-based malware classification

MRes Research Plans

I am pursuing a Master of Research degree to deepen my theoretical understanding of distributed systems security. My planned research focuses on developing formally verified protocols for federated learning that provide provable security guarantees against adaptive adversaries.

YEAR 1

Advanced cryptography coursework and literature review on FL security

YEAR 2

Protocol design and formal verification using proof assistants

YEAR 3

Implementation, experimental validation, and dissertation

Interested in Collaboration?

I'm always open to discussing research ideas, potential collaborations, or sharing insights on federated learning security and adversarial ML.
